Every year, when selecting officials through the **贡举 (gòngjǔ, imperial examinations)**, let them **equal in measure (等量) the recitation of *The Book of Documents (尚书, Shàngshū)* and *The Debates (论议, Lùnyì)*** with one or two **策 (cè, examination questions)**, and let the **策 (cè)** be **prepared in accordance with the number (准数) and added to the *Laozi (老子, Teachings of Laozi)* examination questions**.

That they may **revere and uphold the Dao’s foundation (道本)**, **and supplement the source of transformation (化源)**.

I **sincerely promote harmony with all**,
And if such teachings of sincerity exist,
They must **verify themselves in action**—
How could mere words suffice?

Now, this **effort (劲)**, too,
Should be **kept in every household (家置)**, each must **repeatedly reflect (三省)**,
To **recognize my intent (识朕怀)**.

On the first day of the first month of the **21st year of Kaiyuan (开元, Kaiyuan) reign**.

The **Tang Emperor (唐明皇, Tang Mínghuáng)** again issued an edict to the **太上老君观 (Tàishàng Lǎojūn Guān, Hall of the Highest Venerable Lord Lao)**:

*"Do not stray from **精 (refined essence)**, do not stray from **真 (authentic reality)**,
Take **Heaven (天)** as your ultimate principle,
And the **Dao (道)** as your gateway.
Manifest in **变化 (transformation)**, thus named **圣人 (sage)**.
My ancestor, the **Highest Venerable Emperor of Mysterious Primordial (太上玄元皇帝, Tàishàng Xuānyuán Huángdì)**,
Once **practiced this Way (从事於斯)**.

When **the vault of Heaven (穹昊, Qiónghuāng)** first emerged,
He **paired with the Divine Illumination (配神明, pèi shénmíng)**,
Feasted on **Heaven and Earth (飨天地, yàn tiāndì)**,
Nurtured **all things (育万物, yù wànwù)**.
When the **Emperor (皇, Huáng)** received his mandate,
He **stood as a model among the ranks (师列壁, shī lièbì)**,
And **radiated with unity (熙以大一, xī yǐ dàyī)**,
Bestowing benefits on **the four seas (四海, Sìhǎi)**,
Yet **not speaking of what he benefited (不言所利)**,
His **virtue and teachings (德教)** extended to **all the people (万姓, wànxìng)**,
Yet **he did not boast of his virtue (不称其德)**,
For he **humbled himself at the edges (将晦边也, jiāng huì biān yě)**.

**Stable in guarding the hidden (安乎守藏)**, **yet ready to act (将行道也)**,
**Adapting to the flowing sands (适乎流沙)**, **placing guests (置宾)**—
Thus, it is shown:
**The Dao has no fixed form (神无方)**, **the Way has no rigid body (道无体)**,
**The boundless (冲)** in use is **visible (用可见)**.

Those who **prolong their course (流长)** must **guard their source (慎其源)**,
Those whose **roots are firm (蒂固)** must **deepen their roots (深其根)**.
**Oh, splendid and wondrous (琦欤那欤)!**
**They opened their path (克开厥后)**, **proliferating our ancestral line (繁我列祖)**,
**Illuminating the great central harmony (光启大中)**—
Could **Mysterious Heaven (玄天)** have **privately favored (私乎)** the **Tang (有唐)**?
Only because **Mysterious Primordial (玄元)** **excelled in planting virtue (迈乎种德)**,
Could **Mysterious Primordial (玄元)** have **received the Tang mandate (式受唐命)**?
Only because **Mysterious Primordial (玄元)** **preserved its essence in humanity (存乎其人)**.

Thus, **successive sages (累圣)** **refined the radiance (缉熙)**,
**Reinvigorated the brilliance (重光钻茂)**,
As **great transformation (大化)** gradually **permeated the eight directions (八表, Bābiǎo)**,
And **pristine virtue (淳德)** abundantly **flowed through all lands (万国, Wàn guó)**,
Then **to Heaven and Earth (天地)** there was **a renewal and establishment (兴立)**.

Yet I, **the humble descendant (小子)**, **excel in past achievements (多于前功)**,
**Day and night, I remain reverently steadfast (夙夜敬止)**,
**Above, I inherit the lingering blessings of ancestors (上承祖宗之余庆)**,
**Below, I embrace the joyous extension of the feudal lords (下膺侯王之乐推)**.
**Awake and vigilant (惕然)**, **I dwell in deep seclusion (深居)**,
**Solemn as if driving a decayed chariot (凛若驭朽)**,
For **the *Dao/Way and Virtue (道德)*** is **the foremost of all schools (百家之首)**,
**The refined source (清摩)** of **all transformations (万化之源)**,
**The essential principle (务本)** for **establishing the ultimate (立极之要)**,
**The Way of Non-Action (无为)** as the **gateway to Great Harmony (太和之门)**.

**Reverently upholding (恭承)** the **transmitted beneficence (垂裕之业)**,
How could I **forget the instruction of nurturing wings (燕翼之训)**?

Thus, I **extend with meticulous care (详延博达)**,
**Discuss and elucidate (讲讽精微)**,
Seeking **what governs the state and the self (理国理身)**,
Thinking **of the highest in conduct and the lowest in imitation (上行下效)**—
This has **been long indeed (久矣)**.

To **make all under Heaven (天下万姓)** **drink of pristine virtue (淳德)**,
And **feed on Great Harmony (太和)**,
That they may **turn their hearts in unison (靡然回心)** and **face the Dao (向道)**—
Could this be **my own meager capacity (予寡薄)**,
Alone **achieving such results (独能致此)**?

Indeed, **all in office (凡百在位)**,
So that **all may flourish harmoniously (咸熙)**,
*The Book of Documents* says:
**"The sovereign’s virtue is serene and vast! Oh, the limbs and sinews are strong and upright!" (元首康哉，股肱良哉。)**
It also says:
**"The limbs and sinews are indeed the people; the virtuous ministers are indeed the sages." (股肱惟人，良臣惟圣。)**
This is **one virtue shared in governance (一德而共理)**—
How could it **come to this (至於今)** of **disharmony and confusion (跟整)**?

In the past, **those with long reins and purple robes (长缨紫衣)**,
Still **heard of admiration and emulation (犹闻慕向)**,
And **even broad-browed, high-haired figures (广眉高髻)**,
Spoke of **changing customs (变俗)**—
How could it be that **the Dao is now so difficult to clarify (道之难明)**,
And **the Mysterious Pearl (玄珠, the Dao’s essence)** is **so long lost (久丧)**?

The ancients said:
**"The sovereign’s relation to the realm is like that of a single hall’s occupants." (王者之於天下，犹一堂之上也。)**
Meaning **united in heart and virtue (同心同德)**,
Their **transformations spread to the four quarters (化流四裔)**.
This is truly **the power of sincerity (诚)**—
Whether in **the moment of awakening from confusion (击豕垂踵之惑)**,
Or **the sorrow of turning one’s face toward the Dao (革面向隅之哀)**,
Thus, in **former years (往年)**, I **issued decrees (布令)**,
That **every family should keep the *Dao/Way and Virtue (道德)***,
Hoping that **virtue would stand firm (德立)** and **winds would spread (风靡)**,
And **the Dao would be preserved (道存)** in **daily practice (日用)**,
Then **my ancestral legacy (陈祖业)** would **become the common heritage (尚家书)**,
And **all would follow the Way (出门同人)**—
Without **contradiction in the world (无魄於天下)**.

*The Book of Changes* says:
**"The *xiàng (象, images/symbols)* are indeed **representations of this (像此者也)**."*
*The Classic (经)* says:
**"In the **profound and obscure (窈冥)** there exists **精 (refined essence)**,
Then the **精 (refined essence)** of the **profound and obscure (窈冥)**,
Can be **sought through symbols (寻象求)**,
Yet **cannot be obtained by mere naming and speech (不可以名言得)**."*
Thus, **examining diagrams and histories (考图史)**,
For **every sage and ancestor (凡圣祖)** in their **descents and dwellings (降代出处)**,
I **dare to establish images (敢立像)** to **fully express their intent (尽其意)**.

To **manifest from the family (自家)** to **shape the state (形国)**,
From **the inner (中)** to **the outer (外)**—
Thus, **perhaps those who understand the Dao (知道者)** will **fill their measures (盈量)** and **return (归)**,
And **those lost in confusion (迷方者)** will **not stray far (不远)** before **they awaken (而复)**."

chunks.original_text: 开元二十七年太岁己卯，正月甲午朔，十五日戊申。 真珠洞 按《图经》云：真珠洞者，在龙角山束南峰侧有洞阔八尺，深四十八尺，内渐广深，不可测，每有珠出於洞，因此为号。 先天二年并大历中，尝劫使祭醮玄元皇帝，以龙璧投於洞中。 至晋天佑年，有奉使新罗者，暨至其国，见向之二宝俱泛出水中。 既还长安，因表以进之。 其洞内往往闻笙箫管磬之音也。 庆唐观金练斋颂 朝议郎左拾遗内供奉博陵崔明光纂 空洞之中，瞑津之际，灵文尚矣，混成朕焉。 混成者何，象帝之先，灵文者何，龙汉之年。 五劫交周，尊神递运，九黑列正，元始自然。 冷於流火之庭。 炼於阳明之馆，二仪得之以定位，三景得之以发光，赤明开图，碧落普度，玄元奄有，大道遂荒。 真宗天法之以无，倪皇仰之而未及，牺轩应运，尧舜乘时，均至化而思齐，酌玄风而殆庶，独立千古，湛兮若存，首出百王，悠兮不极矣。 粤若祖圣，系袭神宗，先天不违，后天继代，锡胤庆远，振源流长，国家纂戎，钦承前烈，三合一德，六叶同道。 平阳郡玄元宫者，兴王之肇兆也。 惟初授命，载告休征，权舆灵边，淑落祠宇，昭彰於国史，乃今升平，配永嘉瑞，增修清庙，大建阀宫，明白於御碑，因吾道为天下程，由兹地为天下式，非夫至圣，孰能预之哉。 皇帝御辨无为，斋心正一，寤寝有感，髻鬃真容，昭孝孙之精诚，贻列祖之玄训，开元得圣像，天宝获灵符，丕庆再集而繁昌，至教遂兴而毕备，祇崇册礼，其高莫二，衰龙克光於像设，冤旎追尊於帝位，虽倚那商颂，生人周雅，俦之於昔，今则过矣。 於铄兹山，会神之寓，西对姑射，北邻天柱，皇通仙之秘府也。 正殿肃穆，广庭森沉，峰峦左右，松括交阴，总虚无以静深也。 石坛重阶，饭号环梵，隐诀三五，洞章护持，三元表辰，八月降诞，每至是日，展法於斯，修金录斋，启玉皇印，道家之宝，王者之仪，靡盛於此矣。 乃开乾门，辟坤户，气引广莫，风和不周，八卦行乎其中矣。 仰列宿，蹑魁呈，落日沦阴，夕时沆淦，六甲佐乎其旁矣。 仙倡颁次，羽人步虚，朝拜九天，醮祠五老，想勾陈则黄云垂覆，存太乙则白鹤来翔，其余侍香玉童，传言玉女，缥缈烟景，徘徊元空，求之希微，宛如·契合。 厥惟镇皇极，吋时邕，外以廓清万里，戎夷向化，内以义安兆庶，年谷滋稔，灭格择，兴昌光，动植生成，阴阳气茂，利兵所指，则戢干戈，灵官所临则消疵疠，蚓感通上界，神降棋福，景命来假，天子万年者乎。 观主臣郭处寂虔恭是勤，夙夜匪懈，禀师之录，佩岳之符，躬执科仪，爰谋法要。 开元十六载，御题观额，因隶於兹。 二十五年，上疏议斋，帝俞其请，於是内使高真，自王城而至，纶言秘旨，从天上而来，诸侯肃临，郡邑戏事，革故垣楝。 鼎新经像，彤彩赭赭，金光荧荧，曾是所营，曾是有成，利乎永贞。 太守臣裴眺并寮属等，惟道孚敬，谊形于政，奉歇休庆，皋合观徒众等，皆相与遵，乃宗极体乎自然。 熙淡漠於元和，扑恬愉於大顺。 微臣尝佐汾邑，亲睹圣踪，强名道原，用述真宰从官冥而辨物，因象罔而得之。 其词曰： 三黑之宗，粤玄元始。 朱灵丙午，赤明斯纪。

**True Pearl Cave**

In the twenty-seventh year of *Kaiyuan* (开元), the year *Jisi* (己卯), on the first day of the first month (*Jiawu*朔), the fifteenth day (*Wushen*戊申):

The **True Pearl Cave**—as recorded in the *Illustrated Gazetteer (图经)*—lies on the southern slope of the *Longjiao Mountain’s* (龙角山) bound peak, where a cave eight *chi* wide and forty-eight *chi* deep yawns inward, its depths broadening beyond measure. Pearls often emerge from its mouth, hence its name. During the *Xiantian* (先天) and *Dali* (大历) eras, sacrifices were once held to summon the **Sovereign of the Dark Primordium (玄元皇帝)**, and a *Dragon Mirror (龙璧)* was cast into the cave. In the *Tianyou* (天佑) year of the Jin dynasty, an envoy dispatched to *Silla* (新罗) reported that upon arriving in that land, he saw the two treasures floating upon the water. Upon his return to *Chang’an*, he submitted a memorial offering them to the throne.

Even now, within the cave, the sounds of *sheng* pipes, *xiao* flutes, *guan* reeds, and *qing* stone chimes may be heard.

---
**Preface to the Golden Refining Hall of *Regong* Temple (庆唐观金练斋颂)**
Composed by **Cui Mingguang (崔明光)**, *Zuo Shiyi* (左拾遗) and *Inner Attendant (内供奉)*, of *Boling* (博陵)

Within the **void’s embrace**, at the **crossing of the unseen**—
The **numinous scriptures** shine forth, **mystically fused** with the **Primordial Oneness**.

What is this **Primordial Oneness**? The **Form before the Emperor**—
What are these **numinous scriptures**? The **Dragon-Han epoch’s** decree.

Five *kalpas* cycle in their course, as **divine sovereignty** shifts in succession,
Nine **Black Ones** align in order, the **Primordial Origin** self-so.

Cold as the **Hall of the Flowing Star**,
Refined in the **Abode of Bright Clarity**—
The **Two Compendia** draw from it to fix their stations,
The **Three Luminaries** kindle from it to radiate their light.
**Red Clarity** unfurls its diagram,
**Azure Void** extends its universal salvation.
The **Sovereign of the Dark Primordium** reigns supreme,
Yet the **Great Dao** grows desolate.

The **True Ancestor** follows its law with **non-action**,
The **Naihuang Emperor** gazes upward but fails to grasp it.
The **Sacrificial Oxen** respond to the *mandate*,
As **Yao and Shun** ride the age’s tide—
All strive for **perfect transformation**, seeking harmony,
Sipping the **mystic winds** yet nearly faltering.
Standing alone through the ages, they **abide like the deep**,
First among kings, their **vastness unbound**.

If the **Ancestral Sage** descends from **divine lineage**,
And the **Godly Lineage** inherits the **Sacred Pattern**—
*Xiantian* does not defy, *Houjian* follows in succession,
Bestowing **blessings upon descendants**, extending the **source’s flow**,
The **State’s foundation** is fortified, the **martial clans** submit,
Revering the **ancestral deeds**, the **Three Harmonies** align with **One Virtue**,
The **Six Leaves** walk the **Same Dao**.

The **Playang Palace of the Dark Primordium**—
Its inception marks the **king’s auspicious omen**.
At its first commission, **auspicious signs** were recorded,
Its **sacred precincts** aligned with **virtuous omens**,
Illuminated in the **national annals**, now in this **era of peace**,
It pairs with the **eternal blessings of Yongjia**,
Its **pure temple** is restored, its **grand halls** rebuilt—
Inscribed upon the **imperial stele**, it stands as the **Dao’s model for the world**,
This **land as the world’s exemplar**.
Who but the **Most Sage** could have foreseen this?

The **Emperor**, in his **non-action**, governs with **effortless clarity**,
His **mind purified**, his **will unified**—
In dreams, he **beholds the divine**, his **hair and beard** take **true form**,
Honoring the **filial piety of his ancestors**, inheriting the **mystic teachings**,
In *Kaiyuan*, the **sacred image** is obtained,
In *Tianbao*, the **divine talisman** is secured—
**Grand blessings** gather anew, **prosperity flourishes**,
The **supreme teachings** rise complete.
The **sacred rites and proclamations** reach their height,
No second can compare—
The **Auspicious Dragon** shines in the **sacred effigy**,
The **Wronged Phoenix** is posthumously enshrined as **Emperor**.
Though **Nata’s hymns** and **Zhou’s elegies** may praise,
They pale beside the **glory of today**.

Upon this **mountain’s summit**, where the **divine resides**,
Facing **Gushan** to the west, bordering **Tianzhu** to the north—
A **treasure-house of immortals**, where the **Celestial Way** is kept.

The **main hall** stands in **awe-inspiring solemnity**,
The **vast courtyard** looms in **dense stillness**,
Peaks and pines encircle, their **shadows intertwined**—
All is **emptiness**, **depth**, and **tranquility**.

The **stone altar**, tiered and grand,
Echoes with **chanting and incantations**,
Hidden **precepts** of the **Three Five**,
**Sacred texts** guarding the **cavern’s depths**—
The **Three Celestial Cycles** mark the **lunar phases**,
On the **eighth month’s birth**, the **law is displayed here**,
The **Golden Register** is observed in fasting,
The **Jade Emperor’s Seal** is unveiled—
The **treasures of the Dao**, the **ceremonies of kings**,
None surpass this splendor.

Then the **Gate of Heaven** is opened,
The **Door of Earth** is unveiled—
**Qi** is drawn from the **boundless void**,
The **wind harmonizes with the *Buzhou* winds**,
And the **Eight Trigrams** move within.

Gazing upward at the **aligned stars**,
Treading the **Great Bear’s path**,
As the **setting sun sinks into shadow**,
At dusk, the **mists rise thick**—

The **immortals lead the procession**, the **feathered sages** walk the **void**,

chunks.original_text: 皇上御宇之三祀，春三月，旬有八日，晋慈等州都团练、观察处置使、检校左散骑常侍、兼御史大夫、赐紫金鱼袋李寰斋沐虔洁，祠于神山庆唐观圣祖玄元皇帝。 礼成，谒于高祖、太宗、高宗、中宗、睿宗、玄宗六圣之真庙，灵感昭发，休光动天。 然后登龙角，升华池，陆林岭。 瞻翠微，见瑞梧之奇状，审循葛之延蔓，龙凤交贯，垂于庙庭，次生新枝，有以表圣祚於百万年矣。 上玄之意，必将使茂耸贞固，树之无疆。 当大历十四年之三月，曾生一枝，已备图牒。 当今年三月又生一枝，故知历数昌期，邈不可算，帝王符契，自合玄经。 寰忝列宗枝，谬当廉察，闻斯灵迩，心不遑安，乃首择吉日，礼祈尊像，遂与监军使、朝议郎、行内侍省内府局丞、员外置同正员、上柱国、赐诽鱼袋吴再和、左神策军监铁冶使、朝议郎、行内侍省内府局丞张令绾等，同检验所植柄树高下，葛蔓尺寸，仍令工者图画其形状，具表上闻，乃刻碑阴，用传不朽。 庆唐观碑铭并序 将仕郎知神山县事韩望撰 道母万物，物犹子生，象成太初，囊括元气，抉散氤氲，先天地有，禀立纯粹，保合大和，故天得而清，地得而宁，神得而灵，谷得而盈，王侯得而为天下。 正道苟湮郁，则象无所出，必天不垂日星，地不窍山川，神素阴隐，人窒性情。 故无不通无不具，吞两仪而不见其实，纳毫末而不睹其隘，不可以眸砚，不可以智运。 其象无体，万物之象，其体也，其名无称，万物之名其称也。 不可谓之有，谓之有形其器也，不可谓之无，谓之无灭其变也。 有生於无，无根於有，有无一贯，存於万物，然后见道之妙，物之始。 故日：有物混成，先天地生，寂兮寥兮，独立而不改，周行而不殆。 以是而稽，则知人法地，地法天，天法道，道法自然，而为域中之大者，道冠首焉。 老子仕於姬周，子孙延於汉魏，仲尼见而叹其犹龙，子长叔而为隐君子，事迹蔼然，备载经史。 洎泰山其颓，礼乐之言圯，青牛告逝，道德之论屿，自后以波引蔓延，散而不聚，故扬墨塞路，背仁义之说，庄列当途，立寓言之理，殊不知仲尼、老子，刊六经之秘旨，阅五千之纯奥，与世作程，范围天地。 何则六经之旨正而详，道德之奥和而备，正则父子亲，君臣定，礼乐昭，刑赏中； 和则心以虚，神以清，恶以恢，善以立，故基国树民，包淳剔伪，建皇极，跻寿域，未有遗儒捐道而后臻其理者靡洎后世益腌，前圣逾远，不能宏启其教，但浩扬厥波，故尚玄虚，企羽化，散被峨，冠，目为道士，得徒既繁，大壮观庙，垩泥致像，研丹写形，与浮屠氏并驱，滔源茂林，盛於中国，其来尚矣。 昔隋获神器，炀不固基，征辽幸淮，以人从欲，茫茫九土，民不聊生，怨入骨髓，天下兴叛。 唐公拯疲，参墟启号，义声高唱，响振四海，虽契人心，众盗犹梗，逐鹿之功，未知谁手。 时武德三祀，晋人吉善行於羊角山见白衣老父，须鬓皓然，乘白马朱鬣，仪容甚伟，有二青衣童子侍之，谓善行日：为吾语唐国天子，吾为老君，即汝祖也。 平贼后，汝当为帝，天下太平，享国长久。 太宗遣使者杜昂致祭，须臾，神复见，谓杜昂曰：归语天子，我不饮食，何烦於祭。 忽然不见，上异之，立庙於其地，县是改浮山羊角之号以为今名。

「In the third year of His Majesty’s reign under Heaven, on the eighteenth day of the third month, the **Pious and Pure** (沐虔洁) **Li** (李) **Huán** (寰) **Zhāi** (斋), **Supreme Commander of the Regional Pacification Forces** (都团练、观察处置使) and **Exalted Left Scattered Gentleman** (检校左散骑常侍), concurrently holding the office of **Grand Censor** (御史大夫) and bestowed with the **Golden Fish Pouch** (紫金鱼袋), performed rites of purification at **God Mountain’s** (神山) **Celebrating Tang Temple** (庆唐观), honoring the **Holy Ancestor, Primordial Emperor** (圣祖玄元皇帝). Upon completion of the rites, he paid respects to the **True Temples** (真庙) of the **Six Sages** (六圣): **High Ancestor** (高祖), **Emperor Taizong** (太宗), **Emperor Gaozong** (高宗), **Emperor Ruizong** (睿宗), **Emperor Zhongzong** (中宗), and **Emperor Xuanzong** (玄宗). The **divine response** (灵感) shone forth, and **auspicious radiance** (休光) stirred the heavens.

Then he ascended to **Dragon’s Horn** (龙角), **Hua Pool** (华池), and **Lü Forest Peak** (陆林岭). Gazing upon **Emerald Mists** (翠微), he beheld the **auspicious banyan’s** (瑞梧) wondrous form, tracing the **Bo’s vine** (循葛) as it sprawled and intertwined, with **Dragon and Phoenix** (龙凤) motifs interwoven, descending upon the temple courtyard. New branches sprouted, bearing witness to the **Sage’s blessings** (圣祚) for **millions of years** (百万年).

His Majesty’s **mystic intent** (上玄之意) was to ensure this tree flourish **tall and steadfast** (茂耸贞固), standing **boundless and eternal** (无疆). Indeed, in the **third month of the fourteenth year of *Dàlì*** (大历十四年), a single branch had already emerged, its details meticulously recorded in **maps and annals** (图牒). This year, in the same month, another branch grew, confirming that **auspicious cycles** (历数昌期) stretch **far beyond reckoning** (邈不可算). The **imperial symbols** (帝王符契) align with **mystic scriptures** (玄经), as they ought.

Though unworthy, I was honored to be **counted among the descendants of the Sage** (宗枝), entrusted with **inspection and supervision** (廉察). Hearing of this **sacred omen** (灵迩), my heart could not rest in peace. Thus, I selected an **auspicious day** (吉日) and, with reverent prayer (礼祈), obtained the **venerable image** (尊像). Together with **Brilliant Harmony** (再和) **Wu** (吴), **Supreme Commander of the Left Divine Strategy Army** (左神策军监) and **Iron Forge Overseer** (铁冶使), **Commander Zhang** (张令绾), **Counselor of State** (朝议郎), **Chief of the Inner Attendants Office’s Imperial Registry Bureau** (行内侍省内府局丞), **Assistant Official** (员外置), and **Exalted Upright Officer** (上柱国), all bestowed with the **Golden Fish Pouch** (诽鱼袋), we examined the **height of the planted tree** (所植柄树), measured the **length of the Bo’s vine** (葛蔓尺寸), and commissioned artisans to **illustrate its form** (图画其形状). The findings were **fully reported** (具表) to the throne, and thus this **inscribed stone** (碑阴) was carved, to **transmit its glory undying** (传不朽).

---

**Inscription and Preface for the Temple of Celebrating Tang**

Composed by **Chancellor of God Mountain County** (知神山县事) **Kǎn Wàng** (韩望), **Junior Official of the Way** (将仕郎).

The **Dao** (道) **nourishes all things** (母万物), and things, like children, arise from it. Its **form was established at the dawn of creation** (象成太初), **embracing the Primordial *Qi*** (囊括元气). It **dispersed the misty vapors** (抉散氤氲), existing **before Heaven and Earth** (先天地有). It **inherited the pure and unadulterated** (禀立纯粹) and **preserved the Great Harmony** (保合大和), thus Heaven became **clear**, Earth **tranquil**, the **divine spirit** (神) **responsive**, the **grain abundant**, and **kings and lords** (王侯) **rulers of the world below**.

Should the **True Dao** (正道) be **obscured and neglected** (湮郁), then its **forms would have no origin** (象无所出). Thus, the heavens would **not hang the sun and moon**, the earth would **not open its mountains and rivers**, the **divine essence** (神素) would **remain concealed and veiled** (阴隐), and mankind would **suffocate in their nature** (窒性情).

Therefore, it **penetrates all without obstruction**, **encompasses the dual principles** (两仪) yet **reveals no trace of its workings** (不见其实). It **receives the minutest particles** (纳毫末) yet **shows no limit to its embrace** (不睹其隘). It **cannot be measured by the eye** (不可以眸砚), nor **grasped by the mind** (不可以智运).

Its **form is without substance** (象无体), yet it is the **form of all things** (万物之象). Its **substance is without name** (体也无称), yet it is the **name of all things** (万物之名其称也). It **cannot be called "having"** (不可谓之有), for it is the **instrument of all things’ form** (谓之有形其器也). It **cannot be called "not having"** (不可谓之无), for it is the **transformation of all things’ extinction** (谓之无灭其变也). **Having arises from the non-having** (有生於无), and **the non-having takes root in the having** (无根於有). **Having and non-having are one thread** (有无一贯), **existing in all things** (存於万物). Only then does one **perceive the marvel of the Dao** (见道之妙) and the **beginning of all things** (物之始).

Thus it is said:
*"In the having, all things coalesce,
Before Heaven and Earth they arise.
Silent and boundless, they stand alone,
Unchanging, yet ever revolving."*

By this, one may **infer the pattern** (稽), and know that **mankind follows Earth** (人法地), **Earth follows Heaven** (地法天), **Heaven follows the Dao** (天法道), **and the Dao follows the Natural Way** (道法自然). Among these, the **Greatest in the realm** (域中之大者) is the Dao, which **stands at the pinnacle** (冠首焉).

**Laozi** (老子) **served under the Ji Dynasty** (仕於姬周), and his **descendants endured through the Han and Wei** (子孙延於汉魏). **Confucius** (仲尼) **beheld him and sighed**, calling him *"a dragon still hidden"* (见而叹其犹龙). **Zilu** (子路) and **Zigong** (子长) **were his secluded disciples** (为隐君子), and his **deeds and traces** (事迹) **shone with clarity** (蔼然), **fully recorded in the annals and histories** (备载经史).

When **Mount Tai’s grandeur declined** (洎泰山其颓), the **teachings of rites and music** (礼乐之言) **fell into ruin** (圯). The **Blue Ox** (青牛) **announced its departure** (告逝), and **discourses on Dao and Virtue** (道德之论) **became stranded** (屿). Thereafter, **waves of doctrine spread like trailing vines** (波引蔓延), **scattered yet never gathering** (散而不聚). Thus, **ink was discarded, paths blocked** (扬墨塞路), **renunciation of benevolence and righteousness** (背仁义之说) flourished, while **Zhuangzi and Liezi’s teachings** (庄列) **stood as mere paradoxes** (立寓言之理). Yet they **failed to grasp** (殊不知) that **Confucius and Laozi**, **carving the hidden principles of the Six Classics** (刊六经之秘旨) and **unfolding the profound essence of the Five Thousand Words** (阅五千之纯奥), **set the standard for the world** (与世作程) and **encompassed Heaven and Earth** (范围天地).

Why? Because the **Six Classics’ principles** (六经之旨) are **correct and exhaustive** (正而详), while the **Dao and Virtue’s profundities** (道德之奥) are **harmonious and complete** (和而备). **Correctness** (正) brings **filial piety between parents and children** (父子亲), **stability in ruler-subject relations** (君臣定), **clarity in rites and music** (礼乐昭), and **balance in punishments and rewards** (刑赏中). **Harmony** (和) fosters **a vacant heart** (心以虚), **a serene spirit** (神以清), **the expulsion of evil** (恶以恢), and **the establishment of goodness** (善以立). Thus, **foundations of state and cultivation of people** (基国树民) are achieved, **the pure is embraced and the false discarded** (包淳剔伪), **the Sovereign’s ultimate measure is set** (建皇极), and **the realm of longevity is ascended** (跻寿域). **No scholar has ever abandoned the Dao** (未有遗儒捐道) and **yet attained its truth** (而后臻其理者).

As **later ages grew more corrupt** (后世益腌), the **ancient sages grew more distant** (前圣逾远), and **none could fully expound their teachings** (不能宏启其教). Only **their scattered ripples endured** (但浩扬厥波), so **mystic emptiness** (玄虚) was **revered**, **transcendence** (羽化) **pursued**, and **tall, broad hats** (峨冠) **worn**. The **eyes were called "Daoists"** (目为道士), and though **disciples multiplied** (得徒既繁), grand temples were **erected in splendor** (大壮观庙), **clay statues formed** (垩泥致像), and **cinnabar used to paint their likenesses** (研丹写形), **competing with the Buddhist sect** (与浮屠氏并驱). **Lush forests of doctrine** (滔源茂林) **flourished across China** (盛於中国), and their **origin is ancient** (其来尚矣).

In the past, the **Sui Dynasty** (隋) **obtained the Sacred Mandate** (获神器), yet **Emperor Yang** (炀) **did not secure its foundation** (不固基). He **raided Liao and ventured to the Huai River** (征辽幸淮), **following human desires** (以人从欲), leaving the **vast lands of the Nine Regions** (茫茫九土) where the people **barely survived** (民不聊生). Their **grievances penetrated to the marrow** (怨入骨髓), and **rebellion arose across the land** (天下兴叛).

The **Tang House** (唐公) **rescued the weary** (拯疲), and **the righteous call was raised** (参墟启号). **Voices of justice resounded** (义声高唱), **echoing through the Four Seas** (响振四海). Though **the mandate struck the people’s hearts** (契人心), the **bandits still obstructed** (众盗犹梗), and the **quest for sovereignty remained uncertain** (逐鹿之功未知谁手).

At that time, in the **third year of *Wǔdé*** (武德三祀), **Jin’s** (晋人) **Ji Shàn** (吉善) **encountered a white-clad old man** (行於羊角山见白衣老父) on **Sheep’s Horn Mountain** (羊角山), whose **beard and mustache were snowy white** (须鬓皓然), **riding a white horse with a red mane** (乘白马朱鬣), **of majestic bearing** (仪容甚伟). Two **green-clad youthful attendants** (青衣童子) accompanied him. The old man spoke to Ji Shàn, saying:
*"Tell the **Tang Emperor** (唐国天子) that I am **Laozi** (老君), your **Holy Ancestor** (即汝祖也). After the **rebellious forces are pacified** (平贼), you shall **become Emperor** (为帝). The **world shall know great peace** (天下太平), and your **reign shall endure long** (享国长久)."*

When the **Qianfeng era** (乾封元年) began, the **Emperor Taizong** was posthumously enshrined as the **Supreme High Emperor of Primordial Mystery** (太上玄元皇帝). Thereafter, as the **Earthly Branch’s virtue declined**, the **Wood Branch ascended to the Southern Dipper**, and the **Jin Dynasty** (朱梁) consolidated power, abdicating the **Tang imperial throne** (禅唐寰鼎) through regicide and usurpation, its **heavenly mandate did not endure**. When the **Zhuang Emperor** (庄皇) reunified the realm, he restored the **Tang’s former glory**, thus the **Tang officials** (亳官) once again flourished, and the **auspicious omens of the Tang’s sacred spirit** (唐灵) extended their splendor. These **divine responses across the ages** are fully recorded in the **state histories**.

After the **Later Jin** (石晋) and **Later Han** (刘汉), warlords vied for dominion, leaving no respite for governance. This **sanctuary**, though remote in its mountain fastness and situated in the **southern reaches of Jin**, lacked official resources and labor. Its **ancient foundations crumbled**, and its **structures eroded into ruins**. Earlier, the **Li Tang** (李唐) from **Emperor Shengao** (神尧) to **Emperor Xuanzong** (玄宗) had painted the **six ancient emperors’ likenesses** and enshrined the **three sovereigns** (三皇) in the **main hall**, yet over time, the **colors faded**, and though **disciples gathered daily**, the **glory never revived**. Though the **former traces remained**, the **later ones failed to follow**.

The **Superintendent of the Observatory**, Daoist **Liang Zhizhen** (梁志真), transcended vulgar customs, illuminated the **Great Vision** (大观), renounced worldly desires, and sought the **mysterious and rare**. He believed that **to rectify the end, one must first establish the foundation**, and that **to follow a master, one must first venerate his teaching**. Since later generations could not **embody the Dao and act accordingly**, yet all **gazed upon the images and emulated them**, if this **sanctuary fell into disrepair**, how could it **inspire faith among the people of the four quarters** or **stir the winds of transcendent virtue**?

In the **first year of Jingde** (景德元年), he **set out for the capital**, presented a memorial at the **imperial court**, detailing the **Tang’s origins** and the **auspicious signs of Primordial Mystery**, declaring that **reviving the ancient and honoring the sacred** must await a **sage-ruler’s reign**. The **Sovereign**, embodying the **Great Symbol**, governed with **rectitude and harmony**, sought **Daoist counsel from Kongtong Mountain** (崆峒) and **divine guidance from Gushan** (姑射), rejecting **superficial rewards** and **petty pleasures** to govern with **the people’s welfare as his own**. In this **age of great harmony**, he **promoted the cultivation of non-action**, and thus **approved the memorial**, issuing an imperial edict to **Jin Prefecture** to **restore the ancient halls** and **honor their sanctity**.

Though the **workmen assembled**, the **structures remained unfinished**, when in the **twenty-fifth day of the second month of the second year**, mist and clouds swirled, filling the air with **auspicious qi**. The **silent mountains seemed to receive a descent**. Suddenly, the **morning light cleared**, the **heavens opened wide**, and upon the **altar platform**, a **forest of ancient forms** stood resplendent—**sixteen trees** with **fragrant branches and lush leaves**, their **crystals and blossoms glistening with dew**, sweet as **honeyed syrup**. This **miracle was not confined to the Three Sovereigns’ peaks**, nor did the **sun’s rays dare to dry them**; all present **witnessed it with awe**.

Thus, the **local magistrate was summoned**, who reported to the **prefect**, who in turn **ordered officials to verify the truth**. From **beginning to end**, the **signs endured for eight days** before dispersing. The **prefecture recorded the vision**, submitted a **detailed account**, and sent the **illustrations to court**.

I have often heard that **the Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao**, and the **name that can be named is not the eternal name**. The **nameless is the origin of heaven and earth**; the **named is the mother of ten thousand things**. Thus it is said: **There is the Great Ease (太易)**, the **Great Beginning (太初)**, the **Great Commencement (太始)**, and the **Great Primordial (太素)**.

The **Great Ease** is **before qi manifests**; the **Great Beginning** is **the origin of qi**; the **Great Commencement** is **the origin of form**; the **Great Primordial** is **the origin of substance**.

**Laozi** originally spoke of **substance to illustrate the Dao**, exhausting its depths. He **observed its mysteries without desire**, and **penetrated its subtleties with desire**, thus **communing with the unseen and fathoming the profound**. His **intent transcended mere traces**, his **spirit transformed without constraint**.

Earlier, he **foretold the Tang’s great peace**; now, he **descends upon the Song with sweet dew**. If not for the **proper time** and a **sage-ruler**, who could **harmonize such responses as these**?

In the **second year**, having **ascended to the highest rank in the imperial examinations**, I **began my official career** by being appointed **magistrate of this district**. Following the **prefect’s orders** and **imperial decree**, I **supervised the artisans and the people** to restore the **three halls**: the **Hall of Primordial Mystery (玄元)**, the **Hall of the Three Pure Ones (三清)**, and the **Hall of the Three Sovereigns (三皇)**.

Though the **work was completed**, I did not yet record these events. In the **first year of Xianfu** (大中祥符元年), the **county’s administrative rank was abolished**, and I was **summoned to the Selection Bureau**. Liang Zhizhen **polished the stele** and placed it in the **sanctuary**, requesting an inscription. Though I **declined firmly**, I **simply recounted the circumstances** and composed this **inscription**:

*"The Dao is truly strong, its name precedes heaven and earth.
Formless, it loses no trace—silent, yet never without sound."*

Who traces its profound intent? The *Zhou* historian’s pillar stands firm.

The *Tiansheng Guan* [天圣观] is where the *Tang* Sage-Emperor descended in truth. Its terrain is grand and imposing, surpassing all within the *Hebu* [河束].

The yellow-capped priests scattered, their customs and diets diverging, harming the teaching.

chunks.original_text: 进士王建中撰 盖闻近代已来，屡改神号，进封侯爵，首镒之为华池，中更之为显施，命之为嘉润，三者同出而异名焉。 惟神灵气所宅，森矗山巅，有泉浸于深池，云龙藏乎其中，峰峦摇动，相激而呜，是为圣水出之兆也。 每遇旱岁，所在祈祷兹水，应诚甘贵，靡不沾足，故遐迩蒙其霖泽者，岂止一方而已哉。 伏睹殿基逼窄，楝宇摧毁，孰其揭举。 爰有南李村李隐、上董村陈思恭共发虔心，同为乱首，相谓池逼殿阶，故迁神座丈余问，前植香亭，后筑基址，鸠工集材，轮奂缔构，不日而成。 即择是岁中元节凌晨，就殿告成毕，复诣观褊请道众，严设香斋，及召协力人户，同为庆会。 仆因是日亦往观焉，预命作记，实叔其事，刊诸翠泯，传不朽矣。 时天会十一年中元日建。 重修华池嘉润侯殿记 乡贡进士田蔚撰 窃以亘古迄今，名山洞府，天地神祇，圣迹灵异，或灵显于世，或功加于民，莫不载在祀典，祭献以时，以苔神。 今本县南距三十里有龙角山焉，旧名羊角山，因唐改号。 其山二峰：东峰日华池，西峰日将军，在图经所载，其号古老相传，莫究其详。 其神之灵异，功加于民，莫可名状。 至李唐武德初，太上现於龙角山前甘棠问，见曲沃人吉善行，令报唐天子。 时善行诣朝，具言其事，神尧高祖大喜，遂立观于山前，号日庆唐观。 是时太宗统军在绛，遣杜昂祭於所现处，而太上复现，谓昂日：吾不饮不食，又何祭焉？ 当时居民谓太上所现真身之地，必是洞天福地，益敬其神。 而东峰谓之华池者，而峰上有池，深妙莫测，龙神隐焉。 其池内有石，常时乾争，遇旱则乡民祈祷于池，而其池乾，石上自润而生水，世号华池圣水，乡民请水虔奉供养，无不应感，随水而雨降，故诗人咏之日救旱泉。 当时居民虔奉其神，供敬其池，因建殿于池上，号日华池殿，自唐历五代而之宋，祈求无不应感，而宋赐号显施真人，又进封号嘉润侯，其为华池圣水一也。 其殿既久，殿貌故弊甚，不称灵神安止。 后至岁在癸酉问，乡民李隐独有意焉，于时遂率李革、陈思恭同化集乡众，展其基址，增其香亭，重行修盖，其功美哉，逮至岁在戊辰三月十有四日，忽值天火焚烧，其殿宇尽为灰烬，居民莫不哀念。 又前修殿维那李隐，复率郑锡、陈谏、李革，及本观前都道录阎子美、知观董茂华、郭茂昭、陈惟福、陈惟素、丘惟凝、崔自渊、崔居实，共启虔诚，谓华池灵显于世，功加于民，其神像殿貌，重复修崇，不可后时。 遂斜集乡众，化集所用之物，命工重行修盖，不日崇成，焕然一新，实其美事。 其维那李隐前后率众兴功，不为细矣，及众维那之功，自毕功之后，殊无考记。 若不刊石纪功，则修崇之功无复闻於后世。 时岁在丁丑仲春，仆因假道教学於观前，其元维那命仆为记，非敢尚虚词以襄美，特书其实录以贻后代，传之不朽云尔。 时丁丑岁仲秋二十日记。 祈雨祭文 维大定十一年岁次辛卯，四月乙巳朔，二十四日戊辰，将仕郎、行临汾县主簿郝璟，谨以香荼酒果之奠，敢昭告于华池嘉润侯之神。 窃惟民者邦国之本，神明之主也，故国非民无以卫社稷，神非民无以供祭祀，是邦国之与神明其休戚，皆击於民一体而同患者也。

**Record of the Restoration of the Hua Chi Jia Run Hou Hall**
Composed by *Jinshi* Wang Jianzhong

It is said that in recent times, the divine title has been repeatedly altered, and the deity has been successively ennobled as a *Hou* [侯]. First, it was named *Hua Chi* [華池], then *Xianshi* [顯施], and finally *Jia Run* [嘉润], though all three share the same origin beneath different names.

Now, the divine presence resides where the *qi* of the sacred gathers—towering upon the mountain’s peak, with a spring welling from the depths of the pool, where clouds and dragons conceal themselves within. When the peaks tremble and clash, their resonance gives rise to the omen of sacred waters emerging. In years of drought, all who pray to this water, with sincere devotion, find it sweet and abundant, never failing to quench their thirst. Thus, those far and near who benefit from its blessings are not confined to one region alone.

Upon observing that the hall’s foundations were cramped and its halls in ruin, who would dare to neglect its restoration? Then, Li Yin of Nan Li Village and Chen Sigung of Shang Dong Village, moved by pious resolve, took the lead. They declared, *"The pool presses against the hall’s steps, so we shall relocate the divine seat by several *zhang* [丈], erect a fragrant pavilion at the front, and lay new foundations at the rear."* They gathered laborers and materials, and with swift craftsmanship, the work was completed in no time.

**Record of the Restoration of the Hua Chi Jia Run Hou Hall**
Composed by *Xiangong Jinshi* Tian Wei

From antiquity to the present, sacred peaks and grottoes, divine manifestations of Heaven and Earth, and the traces of saints and spirits—whether their wonders appear in the world or their virtues benefit the people—are all recorded in the sacrificial canons, worshipped in their due seasons, to honor the divine.

Now, within our county, thirty *li* to the south stands Long Jiao Mountain [龍角山], formerly known as Yang Jiao Mountain [羊角山], renamed during the Tang. The mountain has two peaks: the eastern, *Hua Chi* [華池], and the western, *Jiang Jun* [將軍]. As recorded in the gazetteers, their names are ancient, passed down through tradition, their origins unknown.

The divine wonders and virtues of this mountain are beyond description. In the early years of the Tang’s *Wu De* [武德] era, the *Tai Shang* [太上] manifested before the sweet osmanthus tree at Long Jiao Mountain, where it encountered a virtuous man from Quwu named Ji Shanxing. The deity ordered him to report to the Tang emperor. Shanxing then presented himself at court, recounting the event, and the divine Emperor Gaozu rejoiced greatly. He thus established an observatory at the mountain’s foot, naming it *Qing Tang Guan* [慶唐觀].

At that time, Emperor Taizong led his armies in Yan, and sent Du Ang to offer sacrifices at the site of the manifestation. The *Tai Shang* appeared again, saying to Ang, *"I neither drink nor eat—what need have I of sacrifices?"* The locals then believed that the place where the *Tai Shang* manifested was surely a *Dongtian Fudi* [洞天福地], and thus revered the deity all the more.

The eastern peak, called *Hua Chi*, has a pool upon it—deep and unfathomable, where dragon spirits dwell. Within the pool lies a stone that is always dry, yet in times of drought, when the villagers pray to it, the stone’s surface becomes moist and water emerges. This is known as the *Hua Chi Sacred Water*, and those who seek it with devotion find it ever responsive. Rain follows the water’s flow, hence the poets call it the *"Drought-Relieving Spring."* The villagers have long worshipped the deity and tended the pool, building a hall above it, named *Hua Chi Hall*. From the Tang through the Five Dynasties and into the Song, all petitions met with divine response. In the Song, the deity was granted the title *Xian Shi Zhenren* [顯施真人], and later ennobled as *Jia Run Hou* [嘉润侯]. Such is the singular virtue of the *Hua Chi Sacred Water*.

Yet the hall, with time, fell into disrepair, unworthy of the divine’s abode. In the year *Gui You* [癸酉], Li Yin alone took up the cause, rallying Li Ge and Chen Sigung to gather the villagers, expand the foundations, and rebuild the fragrant pavilion. Their labor was magnificent—until the year *Wu Chen* [戊辰], the fourteenth day of the third month, when suddenly a heavenly fire consumed the hall, reducing it to ashes. The villagers mourned its loss.

Li Yin, the former overseer of the hall’s repairs, once again led Zheng Xi, Chen Jian, Li Ge, and the late *Du Dao Lu* of the observatory, Yan Zimei, along with the observatory’s officials Dong Maohua, Guo Maozhao, Chen Weifu, Chen Weisu, Qiu Weining, Cui Ziyuan, and Cui Jushi. Together, they pledged their sincerity, declaring that the *Hua Chi* deity’s wonders benefit the people, and that its image and hall must be restored without delay. They gathered the villagers, collected the necessary offerings, and commissioned the reconstruction. Swiftly completed, the hall shone anew—a truly splendid achievement.

Li Yin’s repeated efforts in leading the people’s labor were no small matter. Yet after the work’s completion, the contributions of the other overseers went unrecorded. If their deeds are not inscribed on stone, the glory of the restoration will fade from future memory.

In the year *Ding Chou* [丁丑], during the *zhongqiu* [仲秋] of the twentieth day, I happened to be teaching Daoist doctrine at the observatory’s gate. The chief overseer then requested that I compose this record—not to embellish with empty praise, but to faithfully record the truth for posterity, ensuring its enduring transmission.

Composed on the *zhongqiu* day of the *Ding Chou* Year.

**Prayer for Rain**
In the *Dading* Eleventh Year, the year *Xin Mao*, on the *yisi* day of the fourth month, the twenty-fourth day, *Wushilang* (a county official), acting as the *Zhu Xianfu* (registrar) of Linfen County, **Hao Jing**, respectfully offers incense, tea, wine, and fruit as an oblation, and ventures to proclaim this prayer to the deity **Hua Chi Jia Run Hou** (Lord of Auspicious Pools and Fertile Rain):

Indeed, the people are the root of the state and the source of divine reverence. Thus, a state without its people cannot protect its ancestral altars, nor can a deity without its people be properly worshipped. Therefore, the prosperity and adversity of the state and the deity are inseparably linked to the people’s fortunes and sufferings.

From this spring into summer, the timely rains have been delayed or excessive. The two crops of wheat have already failed to grow, and autumn planting has not yet begun. The land and the people alike lack food. Every day, the cries of hunger grow louder, and soon they will scatter to the four directions, perishing in ditches and ravines. Then, those who govern the people and receive their sacrifices—how can they find peace?

The deity holds sway over thunder and rain, grasping the reins of wind and clouds. If it rises in majesty, then all living beings in the four quarters will be blessed by its grace, securing the foundation of the state and ensuring the deity’s eternal reliance upon the people. How could this not be glorious?

Now, in obedience to the great prefect’s command, I humbly visit the shrine below, bearing sacred offerings to serve the deity. May the divine dragon gather its essence, and within three days, let sweet rain fall abundantly. This is the deity’s benevolence, the people’s hope, and the good fortune of the county magistrate.

May the deity continue to accept offerings.

**Thanksgiving for Rain’s Return and Water’s Favor**
**Hao Jing**, respectfully offering incense and fruit as an oblation, ventures to proclaim this prayer to the **Hua Chi Zhenjun** (True General of Auspicious Pools) and **Jia Run Hou** (Lord of Auspicious Rain):

Recently, due to the untimely rains, I prayed humbly at the shrine below, and the deity graciously bestowed sacred offerings. Before the second night had passed, the sweet rain responded, and the four borders were drenched. All grains sprouted, the state found tranquility, and the deity’s blessings were also abundant.

Now, I again present sacred offerings to the shrine below, in gratitude for the deity’s favor. May the deity observe this.

May the deity continue to accept offerings.

**Prayer for Rain**
**Guo Yinxiu** and others, respectfully offering incense and fruit as an oblation, venture to proclaim this prayer to **Jia Run Hou** (Lord of Auspicious Rain):

The Dao/Way is boundless, yet sincere devotion can move it. All prayers are made to reach the unseen, relying upon the deity’s wisdom to respond. Now, the season is one of scorching heat, and sweet rain has long been absent. The people’s grievances accumulate daily, and we deeply revere the Supreme Sage’s mercy and earnest aid. We humbly pray that dark clouds surge forth, extending to the distant horizons of the boundless sky, and that the divine dew spreads universally, reaching every place illuminated by the sun and moon.

Let dust settle and crops revive, transforming calamity into abundance, eradicating pestilence and bringing joyous blessings. May every living being bask in Heaven’s grace, all receiving the Dao’s/Way’s nourishment.

**Thanksgiving for Rain and Eradication of Pestilence**
We humbly acknowledge that the divine dragon has bestowed blessings, fulfilling the august ruler’s auspicious signs. The wind and rain have come in due time, fully demonstrating the power of sincere devotion. When misfortune is averted and prosperity ensured, the clouds and thunder merge, reviving withered crops and washing away the lightest dust.

With hearts delighted by the blessings and fields flourishing, we see signs of abundance and know that pestilence will not recur. The granaries hold hope, and old and young alike are free from hunger. Thus, we rely upon the sacred virtue of the Jade Dragon, repaying the True Sage’s favor, sharing in the great blessings, and equally receiving the deity’s abundant grace.

**Prayer for Snow**
**Wang Lianghan**, respectfully offering pure libations and diverse sacrificial foods, presents this prayer to the **General Hua Chi** deity:

The deity has long protected this region for a thousand years. The people know their reliance upon the deity, and thus their expectations are great. Would the deity abandon them now?

Since autumn’s eighth month until today, more than one hundred and fifty days have passed, yet the land remains parched and dust-choked, with no sign of rain or snow. Many among the people are afflicted, and the wheat is mostly withered. Next year’s harvest is in doubt, and the people bear sorrowful expressions. Is this not because Lianghan’s governance is flawed? Or is there perhaps an unresolved grievance?

Yet, if governance is flawed or officials are negligent, how have the people sinned? We humbly pray that the deity, moved by love for the people, swiftly sends blessed snow. May the people have hope for a joyous celebration, so that official levies may be easily fulfilled without fear of evasion, and bandits may cease, allowing all to peacefully tend their livelihoods.

May the deity observe this.

May the deity continue to accept offerings.
